stitches left graft together with kitchener stitch sew onto the body in the spot underneath the line of the mouth and above where the ribbing stops i folded in a bit of the top as i sewed to make it angle back a bit and to give the fin a bit of body at the join 6 of 8 tail the tail is 2 pieces stitched together for a few stitches knit 2 of the following cast on 46 stitches divide on #3 dp needles join in the round 1 knit 23 place midpoint marker knit 23 26 27 knit 2 k m1l k until 3 stitches from the middle 28 k ssk k til 3 stitches from the end k2tog k k2tog k2 ssk k until 1 stitch from end m1r 29 knit k 30 repeat row 28 3 k m1l k until 1 stitch from end m1r k 31 knit 4 repeat row 2 32 repeat row 2 5 repeat row 3 33 knit 6 k until 3 stitches from middle k2tog k2 ssk k 34 repeat row 28 until end of row 35 knit 7 knit 36 repeat row 6 8 repeat row 2 37 38 knit 9 knit 39 repeat row 6 10 repeat row 6 40 knit 11 12 knit 41 50 repeat row 39 and 40 five times 13 repeat row 6 51 repeat row 6 14 16 knit 52 repeat row 2 17 repeat row 2 53 54 repeat row 6 18 24 knit 55 repeat row 2 25 repeat row 6 repeat row 6 until 6 stitches left graft together with kitchener stitch sew tails onto the body i stitched the first 5 knitted row of the tail fins where they meet to each other but that is a judgment call finishing to add the characteristic bumps of the humpback whale i used a doubled-up piece of yarn and a tapestry needle i had the yarn poke up from inside knotted it loosely against the body of the whale and then ran the tail back into the body similar to doing a french knot but you
